thread.title: Construction to begin on $40M Auckland cycleway
thread.title_full: Construction to begin on $40M Auckland cycleway

title: Construction to begin on $40M Auckland cycleway
text:
4:23 p.m. 
Construction officially starts tomorrow on the $40 million cycleway (Photo: Brooke Hobson/3 News) 
Construction officially starts tomorrow on the $40 million cycleway that connects Auckland's eastern suburbs to the CBD via Tamaki Drive. 
The Government and New Zealand Transport Agency (NZTA) have put $26 million towards the project - $10 million of this is from the Government's nationwide $333 million urban cycleway programme. 
Auckland Council will foot the rest of the bill, which amounts to $14 million. 
Minister of Transport Simon Bridges says the new cycleway will be amazing once it's completed. 
"This is just the beginning but it's a very exciting beginning," Mr Bridges said. 
"[Its] a very significant investment in cycleways." 
The Glen Innes to Tamaki Drive path is one of four parts of the project, scheduled to be completed in three years. 
Mr Bridges is confident the project will be completed in time. 

Auckland Transport walking and cycling manger Kathryn King said it is going to be a fantastic resource for Aucklanders to get out and walk and cycle. 
Ms King said there is currently limited options for cyclists and this path is going to be significant as a safer and more convenient option for people who want to get into the CBD. 
The cycling and walking project is the biggest ever to be undertaken in Auckland. 
Mayor Len Brown said it shows how far the city has come in embracing all modes of transport. 
The 7.3km off-road shared path aims to improve congestion and integrate public transport in the city. 
The project is part of a wider $200 million programme of investment in cycling over the next three years in Auckland. 
3 News
